data.title: Update OmniSharp extension message
data.body:
Current:

'Built-in OmniSharp' is now an optional extension. Do you want to install it?

Unless you know that OmniSharp is the extension that provides the C# experience I would probably say 'no' to this question.  We should make this more obvious.

data.body:
Love the new rulers (#1673)!  I find them a little bright though :)  I set them to the same color as line numbers (`#5a5a5a` in the dark theme) and it feels nicer.

data.title: Warning when not returning value from `catch()` in ES6 Promises
[Feature-request] Debug-hover variable when not at breakpoint
data.body:
When remote debugging (GDB in my case) and not being able to breakpoint, it would be super helpful to be able to read variables on the fly (e.g. with hover). The workflow of adding variables to Watch takes forever in comparison and doesn't continuously update.

For reference, this works in Eclipse where hover polls variables between breakpoints.

data.title: Disable intellisense when typing <?php
data.body:
Whenever I type `<?php` and press enter, intellisense autocompletes the item and turns it into this:

``` php
<?php_ini_loaded_file
```

What should happen, is that it should create a new line instead.

data.title: Better sync support

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
There are quiet some extensions out there to handle setting synchronization between multiple computers. And in my opinion they are very important: Since vscode is very customizable with settings, keyboardshortcuts and extension it is very hard to synchronize those things between multiple workstations. And all those extensions are not really clean solutions, because vscode does nearly nothing to support them (for example the paths vscode uses are not exposed, see #2741).

So here some ideas to make synchronization clean and extensible:
- add a contribution point for synchronization extensions
  - Those extensions should not have to gather all the files that have to be synced. vscode should do this and then pass them to the extensions
  - Such an extension's job is only to upload/download the files, passed to them (so we can have the `gist upload`/`svn upload`/`git repo upload`/`dropbox`/`filesystem`/`onedrive`/`ftp`/`other services`.
  - Or maybe gather all settings into one big json object and pass that.
  - Support versioning and non versioning extensions
- add a remote_settings.json to build on top of the workspace-settings/user-settings stack.
- allow automatic and user triggered synchronization

Ok... just some ideas :smile:

data.title: Reaching breakpoint shouldn't show the hidden side bar
data.body:
**Repro steps**
1. open up an editor window with source code
2. set a breakpoint
3. hide the side bar (`ctrl+b`)
4. run the application and hit the breakpoint

When the breakpoint is hit, it shows the side bar automatically if it is hidden.  Typically if the developer has hidden the side bar they usually want to keep it hidden, and usually just debug with the interactive debug console instead of needing the debug side bar bench open.

**Proposed changes**
When the side bar is hidden, if you hit a breakpoint do not show the side bar automatically (in other words, hitting a breakpoint shouldn't alter the visibility of the side bar).

data.title: [ExtensionDev] Expose API to get at file system locations
data.body:
Some extension relay on hard coded paths that are not exposed by vscode. See for example [code-sittings-sync](https://github.com/shanalikhan/code-settings-sync). Those extension are broken in the insiders version. I see t two possible ways:
1. Just expose all paths used by vscode to extensions. Otherwise they will hard code them. No more security, just more messy code.
2. Expose if the extension is used by the insider version. There might be a way, but I have not found it yet. I thought about getting the version and check if it ends with  `-insiders`, but I have not found a way to get this information either.

data.title: Fix #2687: Stop capturing 'REM' as a keyword.command in Batch
data.body: PR #1678 fixed most batch comment syntax issues, but still kept capturing `REM` as a comment, which causes it to be colored differently from the rest of the line. This PR removes the special handling around the keyword, such that the whole line is treated as a comment.

data.title: activationEvents.workspaceContains doesn't fire for directory

data.body: Is this expected?  Also, a general way to detect all workspace-open events, like 'workspaceContains:*' or an onDidChangeWorkspace event would be useful.

data.title: Regexp character class closing bracket should't be part of his beginning match
data.body: When you insert empty character class brackets pair into regex the syntax highlighter doesn't recognize the end of the character class and erroneously highlight rest of the code.

data.title: Can no longer move editor focus when editor is not code editor
data.body:
For the following editors, it is no longer possible to make them active by clicking with the mouse into them or using Cmd+1/2/3:
- binary editor (images)
- binary diff editor (compare 2 images)
- markdown preview

The reason is that I removed the tabIndex attribute from those and thus we no longer detect when keyboard focus reaches them...

data.title: Focus tracking with 2 markdown previews is broken (fixes #2489)
Test extension tips
data.body:
- [x] OS X @waderyan 
- [x] Windows @gregvanl 
- [x] Linux @aeschli 

VS Code can now suggest extensions based on the files you use (open/edit). That that 
- you can access extension tips from the command palette
- you can access extension tips via `ext tips`
- there is a setting `extensions.showTips` that controls if a status bar item shows to indicate that there are tips
- the status bar item is not in-ur-face all the time, it only shows once per extension suggestion

data.title: TypeScript - Find all references not working for default exports
Auto dismiss messages
data.body: Could you add API support to have timeout dismiss messages through the window.showInformationMessage (also warm and error message) API. Requiring the user to have to dismiss these manually can be intrusive if the message is not extremely pertinent. To avoid the user missing the message if they are using vscode at the time it appears it would be good to have a system where the message timeout does not begin until the window is in active use.

I will be really thankful if you guys, allow us to use the comment and uncomment feature with the same shortcut as the other editors do? (just cmd+/ to do or redo it).

data.title: python.configuration.json in extensions is not valid json
data.body:
The python.configuration.json file in extensions/python contains "//" characters on a line in what appears to be an attempt to comment it out. This is not valid json, and an extension written to load this file throws the following exception when trying to parse the json data:

SyntaxError: /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/python/python.configuration.json: Unexpected token /

Attached is an extension class that can be used to reproduce the issue. The class can be added to a VS Code extension project and then run by adding the following two lines to the extension's activate function:

```
    PythonJsonBug.loadJson("java");
    PythonJsonBug.loadJson("python");
```

When the above two lines are run, the first runs without a problem, but the 2nd throws an exception.

[pythonJsonBug.ts.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/118597/pythonJsonBug.ts.zip)

data.title: Add launch option that allows run node project by npm script
data.body:
Hi all,

Looks like current trend to run NodeJs app  via **npm start** or **npm dev**. 
By default, launch.json does not allow us to do this. It`s very unusable. My suggection - to add this feature, that allow easily cconfigure how to run app and not just by parameter "node" and entry point to the site.

Thanks.

data.title: Main menu does not handle Windows High Contrast mode switching well
data.body:
Switch to any High Contrast mode.  You will see odd highlights around the Main menu items (File, Edit, etc).  Switch back to a non-High Contrast mode.  Main menu is now very low contrast.
If you restart VS Code after a High Contrast switch, the main menu is rendered correctly.  Only a running VS Code session after switching has problems.

data.title: Provide link to Insider-specific docs
data.body:
I raised this on Twitter, but just to be clear, there should be an easy way for someone using the Insider build to get to release notes/specifics about the Insider Build. Currently the menu drop downs for Documentation/Release Notes go to the 'real' links for the released version. But there is no way for me to find out what's new in this release. The blog post (https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/vscode/2016/02/01/introducing-insiders-builds/) about this release _does_ tell you where to go, but if you don't have that post bookmarked (or the link), then you're kind of lost.

Basically - provide an easy way for someone running the Insider build to figure out what's new/updated/bugged/etc with it.

data.title: Open File unsnaps snapped window

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
PREQ:
- OS: Windows 10
- VSCode Version: 0.10.6

REPRO:
1. Snap VSCode window to left/right of screen (using Windows Key + right/left arrow)
2. Click File (or Ctrl + O)
3. Click Open File...
4. Select a file
5. Click Open

RESULT:
- VSCode window unsnaps and re-sizes back to original hxw before snap

EXPECT:
- Stay snapped

data.title: change executable name to 'vscode' (or 'mscode' ?)
data.body:
Related: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2679 https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/229

I strongly feel that 'code' or 'Code' is a bad choice as executable name, the former is extremely ambiguous and is asking for conflicts with other packages (existing ones or future ones, or organization-private tools), the latter being rather unconventional on Linux platform to start with capital letter.

Since the community seems to already nickname the product VSCode, why not change the executable to 'vscode', preferrably before GA since sooner is better than later?

Alternatively, if the products name is supposed to be Code (and Visual Studio isn't considered a real part of the name), I'd go with 'mscode' (as in "Code, the one from Microsoft and not something else named Code").

Reasons to change asap:
- The more time goes by, and especially once VSCode gains more command-line options, the more external software will bank on a specific executable name, making a switch more problematic.
- Less post-installation hassle or downright conflicts (especially installing from packages) will mean faster adoption.

Reasons why not to change:
- Other packages have similar problems, like Imagemagick 'convert', 'display' or 'import' (yikes) for example, so no need to make a fuzz about it.
- Some utilities already assume the executable name being 'code', for example dotBunnys VSCode Unity integration plugin.

data.title: debug console loses output
data.body:
When running the node-debug tests I was no longer seeing the output of my 29 tests and I was assuming that my tests had problems:

![2016-02-04 21-57-40](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/12829489/b668380c-cb8a-11e5-9213-3d4cd6f81c39.png)

This screenshot shows how the test result looks in the stable build:

![2016-02-04 22-25-10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/12830181/47784410-cb8e-11e5-8a81-94a1307b2271.png)

When running the test from the command line they finished normally.

After two hours of debugging I suspected that the debug console is losing output. Since I was aware of commit #8761076 I reverted that change and now I'm seeing the full output again (albeit with broken line breaks):

![2016-02-04 21-53-31](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/12829713/d1aff39c-cb8b-11e5-8612-2a8c9a751039.png)

data.title: "Cannot compile modules unless '--module' flag is provided" error even when "module" property is specified in tsconfig.json
data.body: I'm getting a `Cannot compile modules unless '--module' flag is provided` error in Visual Studio Code v. 0.10.6: Here's my `tsconfig.json`, which is at the root of the directory open in Visual Studio Code. Note that I have provided a value for the `module` property: ``` { "compilerOptions": { "target": "es5", "module": "system", "noImplicitReturns": true, "noImplicitAny": true, "noFallthroughCasesInSwitch": true, "preserveConstEnums": true, "sourceMap": true, "outDir": "./src/scripts/compiled", "rootDir": "./src/scripts" }, "exclude": [ "node_modules", "jspm_packages" ] } ``` I've tried other values for the property, such as `amd` and `commonjs` without any luck. I've also restarted the IDE several times. The code compiles with no errors when I compile from the command line. (I'm using [gulp-typescript](https://www.npmjs.com/package/gulp-typescript) for TypeScript compilation. I have TypeScript 1.8 beta installed globally via `npm`, although this problem was also present when TypeScript 1.7 was installed.
